an10.28:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.
an10.28:4.2: Then many lay followers of Kajaṅgalā went to the nun Kajaṅgalikā,
an10.28:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
an10.28:5.1: “Ma’am, this was said by the Buddha in ‘The Great Questions’:
an10.28:5.2: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer. Two … three … four … five … six … seven … eight … nine … ten things: question, summary, and answer.’
an10.28:5.3: How should we see the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement?”
an10.28:6.1: “Good people, I haven’t heard and learned this directly from the Buddha or from esteemed mendicants.
an10.28:6.2: But as to how it seems to me, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
an10.28:7.1: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
an10.28:7.2: but why did he say it?
an10.28:7.3: Becoming completely disillusioned with one thing—completely disenchanted and freed from it, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.28:7.5: ‘All sentient beings are sustained by food.’
an10.28:7.6: Becoming completely disillusioned, disenchanted, and freed with this one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.28:7.7: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
an10.28:9.3: With a mind well developed in four things—seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.28:9.5: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …
an10.28:9.6: With a mind well developed in these four things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. …
an10.28:11.3: Becoming completely disillusioned with nine things—completely disenchanted and freed from them, seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.28:11.5: The nine abodes of sentient beings.
an10.28:11.6: Becoming completely disillusioned with these nine things—completely disenchanted and freed from them, seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. …
an10.28:12.1: ‘Ten things: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
an10.28:12.2: but why did he say it?
an10.28:12.3: Becoming well developed in ten things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.28:12.5: The ten ways of performing wholesome deeds.
an10.28:12.6: With a mind well developed in these ten things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
an10.28:12.7: ‘Ten things: question, summary, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
an10.28:13.1: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief in ‘The Great Questions’.
an10.28:13.4: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.
an10.28:13.5: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
an10.28:13.6: “Yes, ma’am,” replied those lay followers, approving and agreeing with what the nun Kajaṅgalikā said. Then they got up from their seat, bowed and respectfully circled her, keeping her on their right. Then they went to the Buddha,
an10.28:13.7: bowed, sat down to one side,
an10.28:13.8: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
an10.28:14.4: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as the nun Kajaṅgalikā.
an10.28:14.6: and that’s how you should remember it.”
